climbs.name: To Infinity and Beyond (a.k.a. Seventeen Years Later)
climbs.fa: Deb Thompson, Leo Paik, 11/9/2003?, 1st bolted lead Mike Lewis, 5/2/2017

content.description:
This route moves into the round pod on the left end of the Amphitheater Wall. Start as per

Exit Stage Left (a.k.a. Make Your Mark)

if you want the easier start at 5.7. Then move left to the line of bolts heading up and left to the pod. The anchors are just under a small roof at the left edge of the wall. The direct start over the bulge to the first bolt is harder - 5.10-ish.
content.protection: 5 bolts and a 2 anchor bolts with chains.
content.location:
It is left of

Exit Stage Left (a.k.a. Make Your Mark)

. Use the same start as

Exit Stage Left (a.k.a. Make Your Mark)

to keep it 5.7. The base of the wall steepens to the left of this route.

content.description:
This is the (new?) route between

Exit Stage Left

and

Magic Ear Muffs

. If you know the name of the climb, let me know.
content.protection: 3 bolts and a bolted anchor on top.
content.location: The route goes straight up towards the small roof.

content.description:
This route starts with a high, right sidepull and a good left hand crimp. Using the good foot hold on the right (shown in the picture), make a foot switch, and get a far left foot hold in order to position yourself for the high, right pinch. The move up to the pinch is definitely the crux, and be aware that it is kind of sharp. Moving your feet up wherever comfortable, bump your left hand up to one of the two the slopey edges. From there, get your right hand on the super good rail that takes you up to the finish, which is essentially where the positive crack ends about 20 feet up from the ground.

Note: the landing consists of a stump and a few rocks which you don't want to land on from higher up.
content.protection: Bring a couple of pads, I rated this PG-13 just because of the height at which you probably don't want to fall.
content.location:
Navigate to Performance Park or "Amphitheater Wall" in Estes Park. The start of "The Slot" is around the small overhang section, farther left of "

Shrek

" where there are no bolted sport routes. You will likely see the chalk on the right hand pinch higher up.

climbs.name: Shrek
climbs.fa: Tom Dickey, LP, 1/24/2004? 1st bolted lead - Mike Lewis, 5/1/2017

content.description: There are two cruxes with a good rest in between. The first crux is getting from the 2nd to the 3rd bolt. The final crux is getting to the anchors. The rock quality is great. The upper crack may be wet inside, but the route can be down without touching the wet parts.
content.location: This is the left-most route on the Amphitheater Wall. It is overhanging and at the base of the route, you will find a large steel eye-bolt.

climbs.name: Rock Climber
climbs.fa: Leo Paik, et al, 2002?, 1st bolted lead -  Max Lurie, 5/4/2017

content.description: This is the far right route on the Amphitheater Wall. The route has a mid-way 2-bolt anchor for practicing multi-pitch techniques.
content.protection: 6 bolts, 2 anchor bolts/chains. Midway anchor with 2 bolts for multi-pitch practice.
content.location: Start left of the red stone wall, or use the wall if you want.

content.description:
Cool moves, nice holds, overhanging climbing, and a nice flow make this a really fun route considering how short the cliff is.

Begin under the 2 foot roof about 10 feet off the ground - there is a nice jug ledge. Go up to the roof, use sidepulls to get out of the right side of the roof. Move up and left to the 2nd bolt. Share the nice, chalky jug from

Shrek

about midway up, and then move up and right to follow the line of bolts. The few slabby moves at the top are easy but may feel a little scary with a good pump. The original bolted version of the route did not have the last bolt.
content.location: This is the first steep route just left of the slab with all the easier climbs on it.

content.description: This is a link-up of the slab on the Amphitheater Wall. It is worth doing if you've done everything else.
content.protection:
All bolts. This has bigger fall potential, especially when going from

Stage Roof

to

Exit Stage Left

, which is the crux. It traverses hard, so it's just as dangerous a fall for a follower as it is for a leader.
content.location:
Start on the far right side, by the little, constructed stone wall. Climb up 10-15 feet, clip a bolt, then cut left and slightly up across the wall, aiming for the last bolt (before the anchor) on

Stage Roof

. Traverse left of this to just under the roof of

Exit Stage Left

. Climb over the roof, and clip the higher chains of

Exit Stage Left

.

climbs.name: Magic Ear Muffs
climbs.fa: Leo Paik, 2003?, 1st bolted lead - Mike Lewis 5/1/2017

content.description: The crux is getting off the ground. The holds on this route are wonderful - lots of little flakes and jugs. It is a great beginner's route!
content.location: This route is in the middle of the Amphitheater Wall. It begins off the large, blocky, quartz handholds. The anchors are hanging on the underside of the leaning roof.

climbs.name: Hakuna Matata (a.k.a. Cliff Notes)
climbs.fa: Kira Paik, Jerome Larsen, 3/13/2004?, 1st bolted lead: Chris Wood, 5/1/2017

content.description: Like many routes on this cliff, the crux is getting off the ground.  The movement is relatively consistent through the climb.
content.location: This is the shortest climb on the Amphitheater Wall. It ends under a ledge with a bush on it. This is the 2nd climb from the right end of the wall.

climbs.name: Exit Stage Left (a.k.a. Make Your Mark)
climbs.fa: Joe Keyser, 11/8/2003?, 1st bolted lead - Becky Browing, 5/1/2017

content.description: There are two cruxes - getting off the ground and moving toward the final roof. The lowest bolt was placed for stick clipping and to offer some protection for the entry moves.
content.location: This is one of the longer routes on the wall. It heads straight up to a small, juggy roof, and over the roof onto the upper slab to the anchors.

content.description:
This is the second route from the far right of the wall. It is very similar to its sibling to the right, "

Rock Climber

," but just slightly harder.

This route has a anchor station at 35' for easy toproping, then it continues with more bolts to the higher anchor. This route can be used for practicing multi-pitch climbing and multi-pitch rappels.
content.protection: 4 bolts to the 1st anchor and two more to get to the higher anchor.
content.location:
This is left of

Rock Climber

5-10' and is the second route from the cliff's right end.
